text: Lucius Attius Macro was a Roman senator and general, who was active during the early second century. He was suffect consul in the later part of AD 134 as the colleague of Publius Licinius Pansa.Werner Eck, Paul Holder and Andreas Pangerl, "A Diploma for the Army of Britain in 132 and Hadrian's Return to Rome from the East", Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik, 194 (2010), p. 194 He is known entirely from inscriptions. After serving as praetor, Macro was legatus legionis or commander of two Roman legions: Legio I Adiutrix, which was stationed at Brigetio in Pannonia Superior; and Legio VII Gemina, which was stationed in Hispania Tarraconensis. = ILS 2289 Senators rarely commanded more than one legion in their career; in compiling a list of all men known to have commanded two or more, Anthony Birley identified only thirty- three men.Birley, The Fasti of Roman Britain (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1981), pp. 18-20 Attius Macro is also attested as governor of Pannonia Inferior immediately before he acceded to the consulate;Ronald Syme, "Governors of Pannonia Inferior", Historia: Zeitschrift für Alte Geschichte, 14 (1965), pp. 351f Werner Eck dates his tenure in that province from the year 130 to 134.Eck, "Jahres- und Provinzialfasten der senatorischen Statthalter von 69/70 bis 138/139", Chiron, 13 (1983), pp. 170f After he stepped down from the consulate, the life of Attius Macro is a blank. == References == Category:2nd- century Romans Category:Suffect consuls of Imperial Rome Category:Roman governors of Pannonia Inferior Category:Attii Category:Senators of the Roman Empire Category:Imperial Roman praetors Category:Roman legates Category:Ancient Romans in Britain Category:Ancient Roman generals
title: Lucius Attius Macro
